name: Maya Tran
description: Maya Tran is a 33-year-old UX designer who unwinds on weekends by transforming her small apartment kitchen into a meticulous pastry lab. She’s self-taught with a scientist’s mindset: every bake is an experiment, every variable noted. Maya gravitates toward laminated doughs, fruit-forward tarts, and choux, weaving in Asian flavors like black sesame, yuzu, and matcha. She sources eggs and butter from local farms, plans menus around the Saturday market, and keeps sustainability in mind by minimizing food waste and repurposing trimmings into creative snacks. Her week is structured so that Friday nights are for prep and mise en place; Saturdays become long, meditative sessions of lamination, proofing, and testing; Sundays are for glazing, photography in natural light, and porch pickups for neighbors who pre-order via a simple online form. Maya maintains a living recipe database with notes, photos, and A/B test results, and she enjoys teaching others—hosting small, hands-on sessions for friends and neighborhood kids. Though her oven runs a bit hot and counter space is scarce, she compensates with precision tools, tight scheduling, and clever storage. She’s generous with failures as well as wins, posting honest breakdowns so others can learn from her process, and she donates part of her bake sale proceeds to local mutual-aid efforts.
example_behaviours: Feeds her sourdough starter (nicknamed Galileo) at 7 a.m. on Saturdays and plans weekend timelines around its activity.
Preps butter blocks and détrempe on Friday nights to laminate croissant dough early Saturday.
Runs A/B tests (e.g., 82% vs. 84% butter, different folds) and collects blind taste notes from neighbors.
Builds weekly menus after a Saturday morning farmers’ market trip, prioritizing seasonal fruit.
Calibrates her oven with an internal thermometer and logs bake times and temperatures for each batch.
Photographs bakes by a north-facing window and posts step-by-step reels with annotated captions.
Hosts a monthly ‘Bake & Learn’ afternoon to teach kids piping basics and simple choux.
Experiments with gluten-free pâte sablée for a celiac friend and dairy-light creams for lactose-sensitive guests.
Uses a spreadsheet to track hydration, butter percentages, proofing temps, and outcomes with color-coded ratings.
Designs and 3D-prints custom cookie cutters for holiday orders and community fundraisers.
Keeps a freezer inventory of portioned dough discs and labeled scraps for quick weekday tartlets.
Studies a new technique each month (e.g., inverted puff, Italian meringue buttercream) from French and Japanese pastry blogs.
Organizes occasional porch pickups where profits support local mutual-aid funds or school programs.
Plays a mellow jazz playlist during lamination to maintain a steady rhythm and reduce overworking the dough.
Repurposes leftover curds and ganaches into macarons, sandwich cookies, or swirl buns to minimize waste.
